tn.text: The word "See" alerts us to pay attention to what is about to be said.

tn.ref: floods of water are rising in the north. They will be like an overflowing river!
tn.text: The two phrases have similar meaning and are combined for emphasis. The "waters" and "river" both represent the army coming from the north (probably the Babylonians). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"they" refers to the army from the north.

tn.ref: At the sound of the stamping of their strong horses' hooves, at the roar of their chariots and the noise of their wheels
tn.text: Together these represent the sounds of an oncoming army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: roar of their chariots and the noise of their wheels
tn.text: These two phrase have similar meanings and combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This is the name of an island of the northern region of the Philistines. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The shaving of the entire head or portions of the head is a sign of great sorrow practiced by idol worshipers in nations such as Philistia.

tn.ref: the people ... will be made silent.
How long will you cut yourself in mourning
tn.text: The cutting of one's skin was another practice done by the idol worshipers when they mourn the dead.
This phrase refers to the army from the north which Yahweh is using to punish the Philistines. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: How long will it be until you become silent
tn.text: The people of Philistines use this question to express their deep frustration about the devastation caused by their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This refers to the sword of Yahweh as if it was a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The case used to protect the blade of a sword.

tn.ref: How can you be quiet, for Yahweh has commanded you
tn.text: The word "you" refers to the "sword of Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
